_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Tate & Lyle, Loudon is strongly committed to employee, public,  and

environmental  safety.   This commitment  is  demonstrated  by  our

comprehensive  accidental release prevention  program  that  covers

areas   such   as   design,  installation,  operating   procedures,

maintenance and employee training associated with the processes  at

our  facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate  controls

to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.



THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Our  facility's  primary activities encompass  the  manufacture  of

sweeteners,  corn syrups, ethanol, and propanediol  utilizing  corn

wet  milling  and  fermentation processes.  Tate  &  Lyle  has  two

regulated  substances at our facility.  The substances  are  Sulfur

Dioxide   (anhydrous)  and  Ammonia  (anhydrous).   Sulfur  Dioxide

(anhydrous)  is  used to control microbial growth during  the  corn

steeping  process and also weakens the starch-gluten bonds  so  the

separation  process following steeping is more efficient.   Ammonia

(anhydrous) is used as an ingredient in the fermentation process to

produce propanediol.



The maximum inventory of Sulfur Dioxide and Ammonia at our facility

is 144,000 pounds and 65,000 pounds, respectively.



THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS



To evaluate the worst case and alternate release scenarios, Tate  &

Lyle  utilized  the  EPA's  RMP Guidance for  Wastewater  Treatment

Plants.   The  following paragraphs provide details of  the  chosen

scenarios.



THE SULFUR DIOXIDE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO submitted involves a

catastrophic release from the Sulfur Dioxide storage tank.  In this

scenario  144,000 pounds of Sulfur Dioxide (anhydrous) is  released

in  a  gaseous  form  over  10 minutes.   At  class  F  atmospheric

stability,  1.5  m/s  wind speed and urban topography  the  maximum

distance  of 13 mi

les is obtained corresponding to a toxic endpoint

of 0.0078 mg/L.



THE SULFUR DIOXIDE ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO involves the break of

the  2"  transfer line between a Sulfur Dioxide truck and the  bulk

Sulfur Dioxide storage tank.  The scenario involves the release  of

18,000  pounds  of  Sulfur Dioxide.  The existing controls  prevent

bulk tank losses.  The operator and the truck driver monitoring the

truck  unloading will require up to 30 minutes to stop the release.

The  toxic  gas will be released to the atmosphere with no  passive

mitigation  to  control  the release rate.  Under  neutral  weather

conditions  of class D atmospheric stability and 3 m/s  wind  speed

and  assuming  urban topography the maximum distance to  the  toxic

endpoint of 0.0078 mg/L of Sulfur Dioxide is 0.4 miles.



THE  AMMONIA  WORST  CASE  RELEASE SCENARIO  submitted  involves  a

catastrophic  release  from  the Ammonia  storage  tank.   In  this

scenario  65,000  pounds of Ammonia (anhydrous) is  released  in  a

gaseous  form  over 10 minutes.  At class F atmospheric  stability,

1.5 m/s wind speed and urban topography the maximum distance of 3.1

miles is obtained corresponding to a toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L.

THE AMMONIA ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO involves sending a charge of

Ammonia  to  an empty fermentor when no dextrose is present.   This

scenario  would  release  200 pounds of Ammonia  over  20  minutes.

Under  neutral weather conditions of class D atmospheric  stability

and  3  m/s  wind speed and assuming urban topography, the  maximum

distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L is 0.1 miles.



THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL-

SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Tate  &  Lyle has taken all the necessary steps to comply with  the

accidental  release prevention requirements set out  under  40  CFR

part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed  in

accordance  with  NFPA-30 Standard, 1957 edition.   Non-co

mbustible

chemical  storage  systems  were designed  and  are  maintained  in

conformance  with  applicable ANSI standards and chemical  supplier

recommendations.   The  following  sections  briefly  describe  the

elements of the release prevention program that is in place at  our

stationary source.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



Tate  & Lyle, Loudon maintains a record of safety information  that

describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment

design associated with all processes.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



Our  facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards

associated   with  our  processes  are  identified  and  controlled

efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these  analyses  is

the  What  if Scenarios.  The studies are undertaken by a  team  of

qualified  personnel  with  expertise in  engineering  and  process

operations and are revalidated at regular intervals.  Any  findings

related  to  the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely  manner.

The  most  recent  PHA  review for the Sulfur  Dioxide  System  was

performed on September 30, 2013 and the most recent PHA review for the

Ammonia System is 12/10/2010.



OPERATING PROCEDURES



Tate  &  Lyle,  Loudon  maintains written operating  procedures  to

safely  conduct  activities within the  covered  processes.   These

procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-

up,  normal  operation, temporary operations,  emergency  shutdown,

emergency  operations,  normal  shutdown,  and  startup   after   a

maintenance shutdown.  The information is regularly reviewed and is

readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.



TRAINING



Tate  & Lyle, Loudon has a comprehensive training program in  place

to  ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent

in  the  operating  procedures  associated  with  these  processes.

Refresher  training  is provided as needed and  at  least  every  3

years.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



Tate  &  Lyle, Loudon caries out documented maintenance  checks  on

process  equipment to insure proper operations.  Process  equipment

examined by these checks includes: pressure vessels, storage tanks,

piping systems relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems,

control  and  pumps.   Qualified personnel  carry  out  maintenance

operations   with  previous  training  in  maintenance   practices.

Furthermore,  these personnel are offered specialized  training  as

needed.   Any  equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance

checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



Tate  &  Lyle,  Loudon have written procedures in place  to  manage

changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.

The  most  recent  review/revision of  maintenance  procedures  was

performed  on  February 28,  2013.   Process  operators,  maintenance

personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by  a

modification in process conditions are promptly made aware  of  and

given training on the modification.



PRE-START UP REVIEW



Tate & Lyle, Loudon conducts pre-start up safety reviews related to

new  processes and modifications.  These reviews are  conducted  to

confirm  that  construction, equipment  operating  and  maintenance

procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment

in operation.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS



Tate  &  Lyle, Loudon has audits conducted on a periodic  basis  to

determine whether the provisions set out under the PSM rule and the

RMP  rule are being implemented.  The most recent compliance  audit

was  conducted January 23, 2012.  These audits are conducted at least

once  every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result

of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



Tate  &  Lyle, Loudon promptly investigates any incident  that  has

resulted  in, or could reasonably result in a catas

trophic  release

of  a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken  to

identify  the  situation leading to the incident  as  well  as  any

corrective  actions to prevent the release from  reoccurring.   All

reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



Tate  &  Lyle,  Loudon believes that process safety management  and

accident  prevention  is  a  team effort.   Company  employees  are

strongly  encouraged  to  express their views  concerning  accident

prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition,  our

employees  have access to all information created as  part  of  the

facility's  implementation of the RMP rule,  including  information

resulting from process hazard analysis.



CONTRACTORS



Tate & Lyle, Loudon employs contractors to conduct specialized  and

routine    maintenance   construction   activities.    Long    term

relationships have been established with the contractors that  work

on  a  routine basis.  All contract personnel are required to  have

site   specific  training.   This  contractor  training   must   be

documented before a contractor worker is allowed on the  job  site.

The  contractor  safety  representative  meets  with  Tate  &  Lyle

representatives  regularly.   Tate  &  Lyle  and   the   contractor

documents  meetings  as well as investigation reports  to  document

past  safety  performance.  Tate & Lyle  has  a  strict  policy  of

informing  contractors of known potential hazards  related  to  the

contractor's  work.   Contractors are  also  informed  of  all  the

procedures  for emergency response should accidental release  of  a

regulated substance occur.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Tate  &  Lyle, Loudon has an excellent record preventing accidental

releases over the last 5 years. We have had six accidental releases

in the past 5 years.



1) SO2 vapor was released during a plant start-up at the Waters to

Steep tank. An improper seal was provide

d causing SO2 to escape

This occurred 11/30/09. Procedures were changed to avoid this

Situation from repeating.



2) An ammonia drain valve was left open during the unloading of

an of vapor suppression tote on 12/07/09. The operating procedure

was revised.



3) On 06/01/12 during a truck unloading event, the bottom valve gasket for 

the vent line leaked. The valve was replaced. 



4) On 06/05/12 during a truck unloading event, the top valve gasket leaked. This valve was 

replaced with a two-piece ball valve. 



5)  On 06/12/12, an ammonia truck was being unloaded when a relief valve malfunctioned.

The valve was replaced and a mechanical intergrity and failure analysis was performed.



6) A steep fill gate cylinder malfunctioned on 08/20/12 causing a steep to be over-filled as well as a pump failed to pump. Implemented engineering controls, discussed incident prevention with Employees. Changed the sump pump and addressed the need for better water 

management during dry fill systems issues.



7) On 01/22/13, an ammonia leak developed after unloading an Ammonia truck on the manual valve from the Ammonia Heater return. The leak was caused by the valve packing to contract due to temperature/pressure. The ammonia System Truck Unloading SOP was changed to reduce pressure set point during cold weather and developed a preventative maintenance plan to

Check all manual valve bolts and packing. This was added to the Annual Ammonia System

Inspection.



8) On 05/30/13, there was a check valve failure for plant air piping causing SO2 to backflow into air header. The cause was due to improper installation of the check valve. . The supplier of the SO2 installed their own check valves for instrument air connections on trailers. Additional training was given on proper installation of check valves.



9) On 05/30/13, a SO2 leak was detected at a faulty air regulator. The regulator was replaced. 



10) On 06/03/13, an SO2 leak was detected at the SO2 Tank Flange. The b

olts were then tightened securely. 



11) There was a leak on top of the SO2 tank dome lid on 07/08/13. The bolts were tightened securely.



12) On 07/15/13, there was a leak on top of the SO2 tank dome lid. These bolts were replaces and tightened securely.



 13) There was a leak on a hose from a SO2 trailer being unloaded on 07/29/13. The hose was repaired/leak stopped.



14) There were excessive vapors detected during maintenance work on the 3rd floor of wet mill on 08/07/13. This was due to a faulty aspiration system and wall fans. These were repaired.



15) There was a leak in a piping weld on a process water line at the bottom of the steeps tank on 10/08/13. The piping was repaired.ere excessive vapors detected during maintenance work on the 3rd floor of wet mill on 10/08/13. This was due to a faulty aspiration system and wall fans. These were repaired.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



Tate  &  Lyle,  Loudon  has a written emergency  response  plan  to

address  accidental  releases  of hazardous  materials.   The  plan

includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first

aid  and  medical  treatment, evacuations,  notification  of  local

emergency response agencies and the public as well as post-incident

decontamination of affected areas.



To  ensure proper functioning, the emergency response equipment  is

regularly  inspected  and  serviced.   In  addition,  the  plan  is

promptly  updated  to  reflect any pertinent changes  taking  place

within  the  processes  that  would require  a  modified  emergency

response.



Loudon  County Emergency Planning Committee is the Local  Emergency

Planning  Committee  with  which  our  emergency  plans  has   been

coordinated and verified.
